Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Jamie, my best friend. I glanced at it between radio calls. “I can’t believe you’d say that. I thought you understood me.” My heart dropped. I reread my earlier text—meant as a joke, but I could see how it sounded harsh. Jamie needed to hear my voice, to know I cared, to clear this up before it festered. I reached for my phone, thumb hovering over the call button.

But the radar screen blinked urgently. “Tower, this is Delta 214, requesting climb instructions. Cloud tops are building fast.” Three other pilots echoed similar requests. My headset crackled with their voices, each one depending on me to keep them safe, to give clear, immediate directions. My job demanded my full attention, no distractions, not even for a minute.

I stared at my phone, Jamie’s hurt message glowing on the screen, while the radio filled with pilots’ anxious voices. My chest tightened. My friend needed me now, but so did the pilots in the sky. I felt torn in two, the weight of both worlds pressing down, and I had to choose which voice to answer first.
